ENVIRONMENTAL ADVISORY BOARD
§ 32.100 ESTABLISHMENT AND INTENT.
   There is hereby established a Pembroke Pines Environmental Advisory Board,
which shall serve in an advisory capacity to the City Commission. (Ord. 941,
passed 11-28-90; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11; Am. Ord. 1869, passed 2-15-17)
§ 32.101 EX OFFICIO MEMBERS; APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS; COMPOSITION, QUORUM.
   (A)   The Environmental Advisory Board shall consist of 11 regular members
and one alternate member. Additionally the following ex officio members who
shall have no voting powers on the Board, to wit: the City Manager, or his/her
designee, and a Board Secretary.
   (B)   Each member of the City Commission shall appoint two members to the
Environmental Advisory Board, with the Mayor appointing three members and one
alternate member. All appointments shall be made pursuant to the City Code. All
persons considered for appointment, to the extent practicable, shall represent
environmental interests, specialties and qualifications in the following field:
      (1)   Architecture;
      (2)   Biology;
      (3)   Education;
      (4)   Engineering;
      (5)   Environmental science;
      (6)   Forestry;
      (7)   Geology;
      (8)   Horticulture;
      (9)   Law;
      (10)   Urban Planning.
   (C)   Six members in attendance shall constitute a quorum of the
Environmental Advisory Board. (Ord. 941, passed 11-28-90; Am. Ord. 1697, passed
9-7-11; Am. Ord. 1869, passed 2-15-17)
§ 32.102 OBJECTIVES; PURPOSES.
   The objectives and purposes of the Environmental Advisory Board shall be to
provide constructive advice and counsel to the City Commission, with a broad
outlook toward environmental protection and conservation in the following
manner:
   (A)   Advise the City Commission with regards to implementation of the
city's adopted Green Plan;
   (B)   Advise the City Commission with regards to environmental
sustainability and planning;
   (C)   Review and advise the City Commission with regards to best practices
in arboriculture, forestry, recycling, waste reduction and litter abatement;
   (D)   Review and advise the City Commission with regards to regional or
emerging issues such as water and air quality, fracking, dark skies and/or
airborne diseases;
   (E)   Review and advise the City Commission with regards to community
supported agricultural initiatives or regional food supply or food deserts;
   (F)   Review and advise the City Commission with regards to alternate
transportation options such as bicycle, pedestrian and mass transit:
   (G)   Review and advise the City Commission with regards to wildlife and/or
wildlife habitats;
   (H)   Identify and recommend affordable strategies associated with
conservation, renewable energy and energy efficiency;
   (I)   Research environmentally sound practices that will reduce greenhouse
gas emissions, save money, energy and natural resources;
   (J)   Make recommendations and then promote projects that beautify and
improve the aesthetic of the city;
   (K)   Provide recommendations to the City Commission on the adoption,
prioritization and implementation of initiatives, actions, policies, and public
outreach and education programs to support and promote all aspects of
sustainabilitv and/or going green;
   (L)   Research financial initiatives and resources to offset costs;
   (M)   Develop and recommend outcome measures for green programs and
initiatives;
   (N)   Participate in city events to promote Green practices to further the
Board's mission and purpose;
   (O)   Monitor the progress of approved initiatives and identify and address
stumbling blocks to their implementation, to ensure that sustainabilitv
benefits are achieved and strategic plans to achieve said benefits are
implemented in a reasonable timeframe;
   (P)   Investigate, research and make recommendations regarding the
Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) Green Building Rating
System and other environmental programs and green technologies which may be of
interest to the city and its residents and businesses;
   (Q)   Make recommendations and/or advise other City Advisory Boards in
regards to environmental issues. (Ord. 941, passed 11-28-90; Am. Ord. 1697,
passed 9-7-11; Am. Ord. 1869, passed 2-15-17)
§ 32.103 MEETINGS.
   The Environmental Advisory Board meetings will meet on the first Tuesday of
every month or as needed. (Ord. 941, passed 11-28-90; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-
7-11; Am. Ord. 1869, passed 2-15-17)
CHARTER SCHOOL ADVISORY BOARD
§ 32.110 ESTABLISHMENT AND INTENT.
   (A)   It is the intent of the City Commission in the establishment of the
Charter School Advisory Board that this Board shall act in an advisory capacity
to the City Commission in matters relating to the city’s charter schools.
   (B)   It is the further intent and purpose in the creation of the Pembroke
Pines Charter School Advisory Board that the Board shall serve in a responsive
capacity to the needs of the community, the charter schools, the schoolchildren
and their parents so as to assist in the ability of the charter school to
foster a positive and creative liaison between the City Commission and the
charter school community.
   (C)   It is the further intent of the City Commission that a separate
Advisory Board shall be created for the Charter Elementary School, the Charter
Middle School and the Charter High School. The commencement of each Advisory
Board shall precede the opening of each respective school. (Ord. 1265, passed
6-17-98; Am. Ord. 1314, passed 9-1-99; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.111 DUTIES.
   The duties of the Pembroke Pines Charter School Advisory Board shall include
but not be limited to the following:
   (A)   Observe effectiveness of school operations;
   (B)   Review of principal’s policies regarding such issues as attendance and
discipline;
   (C)   Perform fiscal review and submit recommendations to the city;
   (D)   Provide evaluation input with regard to the performance of the
principal to the City Manager;
   (E)   Provide periodic reports to City Commission including an end-of-year
annual report;
   (F)   Recommend curriculum initiatives to the city in cooperation with the
principal;
   (G)   Serve and offer leadership on selected subcommittees;
   (H)   Assist in the development of long range strategic plans to establish
comprehensive vision of the city’s educational initiatives;
   (I)   Assist and advise in development efforts including grant
administration and other fund raising efforts; and
   (J)   To abide by the goals and objectives and fulfill the requirements of
the Charter School application made by the city to the Broward County School
Board. (Ord. 1265, passed 6-17-98; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.112 BOARD ACTION ADVISORY ONLY.
   The actions, decisions and recommendations of the Pembroke Pines Charter
School Advisory Board shall not be final or binding on the City Commission, but
shall be advisory only. The Board or its members shall coordinate all
recommendations for improvement in the operation of the Pembroke Pines Charter
Schools through the Charter School Principal and shall not interact directly
with the Charter School administration and staff, except for the purpose of
inquiries, investigations, and observations consistent with the provisions of §
3.07 of the Pembroke Pines Charter. (Ord. 1265, passed 6-17-98; Am. Ord. 1697,
passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.113 COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS; TERMS OF APPOINTMENT.
   The Pembroke Pines Charter School Advisory Board shall consist of nine
members, seven of which shall be voting members.
   (A)   Non-voting members: The City Manager, or his/her designee, and the
Principal of the Charter Schools shall serve as ex officio, non-voting members.
   (B)   Voting members:
      (1)   An individual possessing definable experience in educational and
administrative matters shall be appointed by a majority of the City Commission.
      (2)   Five additional voting members and two alternates shall consist of
parents of those students enrolled in the Pembroke Pines Charter Schools and
shall be elected by the parents of the Pembroke Pines Charter School students
for a one year term commencing October 1 until September 30. The initial parent
members shall be selected and appointed by the City Commission and shall serve
until September 30, 1999.
      (3)   The remaining voting members shall be business representatives of
the community selected and appointed by a majority of the City Commission and
shall serve a two year terms commencing October 1 until September 30. The
initial business representative members shall be selected and appointed by the
City Commission to serve until September 30, 2000.
   (C)   Each parent, business representative, and alternate member of the
Board shall serve until the expiration of his or her term, resignation, removal
for cause, or until a successor is appointed by the respective appointing body,
except that the City Manager, or his/her designee, and the Principal shall
remain as permanent members of the Board. Removal for cause shall take effect
immediately, upon approval of such removal by the City Commission. (Ord. 1265,
passed 6-17-98; Am. Ord. 1306, passed 6-2-99; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.114 QUALIFICATIONS OF MEMBERSHIP.
   The qualifications for membership shall be as follows:
   (A)   The City Commission’s educational and administrative appointee shall
demonstrate definable experience in administrative matters in an educational
setting and shall serve a one year term commencing October 1 until September
30.
   (B)   Each parent member of the Board shall have a student enrolled in a
Pembroke Pines Charter School. As no students will be enrolled at the time of
the appointment of the initial parent members of this Board, the initial parent
members are exempt from this requirement.
   (C)   Each business representative serving on the Board shall either reside
in the city or do business within the boundaries of the city, evidenced by a
valid, current local business tax receipt issued by the city.
   (D)   Each applicant shall indicate his or her interest in becoming well-
versed with the City of Pembroke Pines Charter and Code of Ordinances as the
same may apply to the operation and administration of the Pembroke Pines
Charter Schools and shall be further interested in the development and
operations of the Pembroke Pines Charter School programs to best serve the
health, safety and welfare of the citizen and residents of the city and Broward
County, Florida. (Ord. 1265, passed 6-17-98; Am. Ord. 1306, passed 6-2-99; Am.
Ord. 1576, passed 4-18-07; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.115 MEETINGS, DATES, PROCEDURES, RECORDS AND QUORUM.
   (A)   An organizational meeting of the Charter School Advisory Board shall
be held as the first meeting of each year, or as soon thereafter as
practicable, for the purpose of electing officers for the ensuing year. A Chair
and Vice Chair shall be elected for terms of one year by the Board from its
voting membership. At least one regular meeting of the Board shall be held each
month and special meetings may be called by the Chair or by any five voting
members of the Board.
   (B)   Five voting members in attendance shall constitute a quorum of the
Board. (Ord. 1265, passed 6-17-98; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.116 ASSISTANCE TO THE BOARD.
   The City Clerk or his/her designee shall act as secretary to the Board and
be responsible for providing the items necessary for conducting meetings, as
requested by the Chair of the Board, and for recording and preparation of
meeting minutes. The City Attorney or his/her designee shall act as the
attorney for the Board. (Ord. 1265, passed 6-17-98; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-
11)
§ 32.117 FUNDING.
   The City Commission shall appropriate funds at its discretion to the Board
for expenses necessary in the conduct of its work. The Board, upon the approval
of the City Commission, may accept grants or other monetary and physical
assistance to aid in its work. (Ord. 1265, passed 6-17-98; Am. Ord. 1697,
passed 9-7-11)
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT BOARD
§ 32.120 ESTABLISHMENT AND INTENT.
   (A)   It is the intent of the City Commission in the establishment of the
Pembroke Pines Economic Development Board that this Board shall act in an
advisory capacity to the City Commission for the express purposes of pursuing
new business opportunities as well as assisting local businesses and business
operations in enhancing and in solidifying their existing conditions and roles
within the city and the business environment of Broward County, Florida.
   (B)   It is the further intent and purpose in the creation of the Pembroke
Pines Economic Development Board that the Board shall serve as a voice and in a
responsive capacity to the needs of local businesses and business operations so
as to assist local businesses and business operations in their ability to
continue to do business in this city and to foster a positive and creative
liaison between the City Commission and local businesses. (Ord. 1289, passed
11-4-98; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.121 DUTIES.
   The duties of the Pembroke Pines Economic Development Board shall be as
follows:
   (A)   To act in an advisory capacity to the City Commission; to conduct and
hold public meetings in which matters affecting local businesses and local
business activities to the city shall be considered, analyzed and reviewed for
the express purposes of enhancing and enlightening the relationship between
local government and local businesses in this city.
   (B)   To review and to formulate recommendations to the City Commission on
specific business issues or business matters which reflect upon specific
economic conditions or business matters which could, through legislation or
other public action, be resolved or alleviated by actions taken or to be taken
by the City Commission or the City Administration.
   (C)   To periodically review business matters affected by the Comprehensive
Zoning Ordinances of the city, the city’s Comprehensive Land Use Plan, the
city’s Comprehensive Land Use map, and other land development regulations
which, by their terms or by implication have an effect upon the operation of
local businesses and business operations which require the attention and
further consideration of the City Commission.
   (D)   To accept the responsibility of periodic specific assignments from the
City Commission to consider and to analyze matters which may be of a general or
specific concern to the City Commission, or otherwise required by ordinance.
(Ord. 1289, passed 11-4-98; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.122 BOARD ACTION ADVISORY ONLY.
   The actions, decisions, and recommendations of the Pembroke Pines Economic
Development Board shall not be final or binding on the City Commission, but
shall be advisory only. (Ord. 1289, passed 11-4-98; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-
11)
§ 32.123 COMPOSITION: APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS.
   (A)   The Pembroke Pines Economic Development Board shall consist of 11
members and one alternate, as provided for hereinafter.
   (B)   Each member of the City Commission shall appoint one member
representing their district with the Mayor’s appointee chosen at large to serve
on the Pembroke Pines Economic Development Board.
   (C)   The City Commission, by majority vote, shall appoint two additional
voting members. These two members shall serve a term of two years each.
   (D)   The Mayor shall appoint one alternate member.
   (E)   The City Commission shall direct the City Manager, or his or her
designee, to serve as an ex-officio member of the Pembroke Pines Economic
Development Board during his or her term as City Manager of the city.
   (F)   The Miramar/Pembroke Pines Chamber of Commerce, or any successor
organization, shall nominate four members to be appointed by a majority of the
City Commission and shall serve an initial term of one year.
   (G)   Unless otherwise provided for in this section, each member of the
Board shall serve at the pleasure of the appointing member of the City
Commission. The Miramar/Pembroke Pines Chamber of Commerce, or its successor,
shall be permitted to re-nominate a member to serve on the Pembroke Pines
Economic Development Board for approval by the City Commission. (Ord. 1289,
passed 11-4-98; Am. Ord. 1522, passed 9-7-05; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.124 QUALIFICATIONS OF MEMBERSHIP.
   (A)   The qualifications for membership shall be as follows:
      (1)   The applicant/members appointed by the City Commission may be full-
time residents of the city for not less than a period of six months immediately
prior to the appointment or;
      (2)   The City Commission shall endeavor to appoint members who are local
business persons doing business in the city and who possess local business tax
receipts issued by the city. However, Pembroke Pines residents, if available,
who otherwise meet the qualifications of this subchapter but who are local
business persons outside the city, shall also be considered for appointment. In
the event that members of the Commission are unable to appoint members to this
Board who qualify as local business persons, then the City Commission shall be
free to appoint persons who otherwise demonstrate their strong and sincere
commitment to the legislative intent set forth in this subchapter.
      (3)   All persons considered for appointment by the City Commission shall
demonstrate a specific interest in the preservation, generation, and
enhancement of local businesses and local business operations in the city which
shall be demonstrated by an objective statement of commitment by such person to
foster a more comprehensive and positive business climate in the city.
      (4)   Each applicant shall indicate his or her interest in becoming well-
versed with the City of Pembroke Pines Charter and Code of Ordinances as
amended from time to time as the same may apply to businesses and business
operations and shall be further interested in the business development of
business activities and operations in the city to best serve the health,
safety, and welfare of the city. (Ord. 1289, passed 11-4-98; Am. Ord. 1576,
passed 4-18-07; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.125 MEETINGS, DATES, PROCEDURES, RECORDS, AND QUORUM.
   (A)   An organizational meeting of the Economic Development Board shall be
held at the first meeting of the Board after their appointment and thereafter
at the first regular meeting in the month of July of each year or as soon
thereafter as practicable, for the purpose of electing officers for the ensuing
year. A chairman and vice-chairman shall be elected for terms of one year by
the Board from its membership. At least one regular meeting of the Board shall
be held each month and special meetings may be called by the chairman or by any
five regular members of the Board.
   (B)   Six members in attendance shall constitute a quorum of the Board.
(Ord. 1289, passed 11-4-98; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.126 ASSISTANCE TO THE BOARD.
   The City Manager, or his or her designee, shall attend Board meetings and
provide assistance and advice to the Board in its deliberations. The City Clerk
shall act as secretary to the Board and be responsible for providing the items
necessary for conducting meetings, as requested by the chairman of the Board,
and for recording of meeting minutes. (Ord. 1289, passed 11-4-98; Am. Ord.
1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.127 FUNDING.
   The City Administration may budget appropriate funds, at the discretion of
the City Commission, to the Board for expenses necessary in the conduct of its
work. The Board, upon the approval of the City Commission, may accept grants
for other monetary and physical assistance to aid in its work. (Ord. 1289,
passed 11-4-98; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
ARTS AND CULTURE ADVISORY BOARD
§ 32.130 ESTABLISHMENT AND INTENT.
   (A)   It is the intent of the City Commission in the establishment of the
Arts and Culture Advisory Board that this Board shall act in an advisory
capacity to the City Commission in matters relating to arts and culture within
the city.
   (B)   It is the further intent and purpose in the creation of the Arts and
Culture Advisory Board that the Board shall serve as a voice and in a
responsive capacity to the artistic and cultural needs of the community, to
encourage artistic opportunities for the residents, citizens and visitors of
the city and to foster a positive and creative liaison between City Commission
and the artistic community. (Ord. 1367, passed 1-17-01; Am. Ord. 1697, passed
9-7-11)
§ 32.131 DUTIES.
   The duties of the Arts and Culture Advisory Board shall include but not be
limited to the following:
   (A)   Identify artistic and cultural opportunities in the city and county.
   (B)   Seek out artists and performers to exhibit or perform for the citizens
residents and visitors of the city.
   (C)   Assist and advise the City Commission in an effort to address the
cultural needs of the city.
   (D)   Develop opportunities and recommend initiatives in cooperation with
the city for artisans to provide exposure to their craft.
   (E)   Assist in the development of long range strategic plans to establish
comprehensive vision of the city’s cultural initiatives;
   (F)   Assist and advise in development efforts including grant
administration and other fund raising efforts. (Ord. 1367, passed 1-17-01; Am.
Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.132 BOARD ACTION ADVISORY ONLY.
   The actions, decisions and recommendations of the Arts and Culture Advisory
Board shall not be final or binding on the City Commission, but shall be
advisory only. The Board or its members shall coordinate all recommendations
for improvement in the cultural experience in the city and shall not interact
directly with city administration and staff, except for the purpose of
inquiries, investigations, and observations consistent with the provisions of
3.07 of the City Charter. (Ord. 1367, passed 1-17-01; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-
7-11)
§ 32.133 COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS.
   (A)   The Arts and Culture Advisory Board shall consist of seven permanent
members who shall be voting members and two alternate members. Alternate
members shall be permitted to vote in the absence of permanent members provided
that no more than seven members vote on any action being considered by the
Board. Five members of the Board shall be selected and appointed in accordance
with §
32.004. Two additional voting members appointed by the City Commission and two
alternates shall be appointed by the Mayor. The two members appointed by the
City Commission shall serve a two-year term.
   (B)   The Arts and Culture Advisory Board may, at its option, appoint non-
voting members of the Board to serve as “Friends of the Arts and Culture
Advisory Board.”
   (C)   The City Manager, or his/her designee, and the Director of the City’s
Parks and Recreation Department, or his/her designee, shall serve as ex
officio, non-voting members and shall remain as permanent members of the Board.
(Ord. 1367, passed 1-17-01; Am. Ord. 1640, passed 5-6-09; Am. Ord. 1697, passed
9-7-11)
§ 32.134 QUALIFICATION OF MEMBERSHIP.
   The qualifications for membership shall be as follows:
   (A)   Each member of the Board shall be a resident of the city.
   (B)   No member of the Board may recommend their own artistic creations or
cultural exhibits to the Board for display or performance.
   (C)   Each applicant shall indicate his or her interest in becoming well-
versed with the City Charter and Code of Ordinances as the same may apply to
the operation and administration of the Board and shall be further interested
in the development of programs to best serve the health, safety and welfare of
the citizens and residents of the city and county. (Ord. 1367, passed 1-17-01;
Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.135 MEETINGS, DATES, PROCEDURES, RECORDS AND QUORUM.
   (A)   An organizational meeting of the Arts and Culture Advisory Board shall
be held as the first meeting of each year, or as soon thereafter as
practicable, for the purpose of electing officers for the ensuing year. A Chair
and Vice Chair shall be elected for terms of one year by the Board from its
voting membership. At least one regular meeting of the Board shall be held each
month and special meetings may be called by the Chair or by any five voting
members of the Board.
   (B)   The Board may designate sub-committees to perform fact-finding
functions. Each sub-committees shall report back to the Board during regular or
special meetings of the Board to advise the Board as a whole and report all
information collected in order for the Board to take further action.
   (C)   Five voting members in attendance shall constitute a quorum of the
Board. (Ord. 1367, passed 1-17-01; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.136 ASSISTANCE TO THE BOARD.
   The City Clerk or his/her designee shall act as secretary to the Board and
be responsible for providing the items necessary for conducting meetings, as
requested by the Chair of the Board, and for recording and preparation of
meeting minutes. The City Attorney, or his/her designee, shall act as the
attorney for the Board. (Ord. 1367, passed 1-17-01; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-
11)
§ 32.137 FUNDING.
   The City Commission shall appropriate funds at its discretion to the Board
for expenses necessary in the conduct of its work. The Board, upon the approval
of the City Commission, may accept grants or other monetary and physical
assistance to aid in its work. All funds raised by the Board are public funds.
City Commission approval shall be required for any expenditures by the Board.
(Ord. 1367, passed 1-17-01; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
RIVER OF GRASS CULTURAL ARTS CENTER ADVISORY BOARD
§ 32.138 ESTABLISHMENT AND INTENT.
   (A)   It is the intent of the City Commission in the establishment of the
River of Grass Cultural Arts Center Advisory Board that this Board shall act in
an advisory capacity to the City Commission in matters relating to the River of
Grass Cultural Arts Center.
   (B)   It is further the intent and purpose in the creation of the River of
Grass Cultural Arts Center Advisory Board that the Board shall facilitate the
management and production of the cultural programming at the River of Grass
Cultural Arts Center and to foster a positive and creative liaison between the
City Commission and the community for the effective utilization of the River of
Grass Cultural Arts Center. (Ord. 1439, passed 4-2-03; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-
7-11)
§ 32.139 DUTIES.
   The duties of the River of Grass Cultural Arts Center Advisory Board shall
include, but not be limited to, the following:
   (A)   Solicit corporate sponsorship and grant funding for programs and
special events and performances in the River of Grass Cultural Arts Center;
   (B)   Advise the City Commission in an effort to address the cultural and
educational needs of all citizens;
   (C)   Assist in the development of the Program Goals and Plan for the
operation of the River of Grass Cultural Arts Center;
   (D)   Recommend events and programming at the River of Grass Cultural Arts
Center in furtherance of the program goals and plan; and
   (E)   Develop and identify cooperative opportunities with community
organizations for the benefit of the River of Grass Cultural Arts Center. (Ord.
1439, passed 4-2-03; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.140 BOARD ACTION ADVISORY ONLY.
   The actions, decisions and recommendations of the River of Grass Cultural
Arts Center shall not be final or binding on the City Commission, but shall be
advisory only. The Board or its members shall coordinate all recommendations on
behalf of the Center with the city and shall not interact directly with city
administration and staff, except for the purpose of inquiries, investigations,
and observations consistent with the provisions of §
3.07 of the City Charter. (Ord. 1439, passed 4-2-03; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-
11)
§ 32.141 COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS; TERMS OF APPOINTMENT.
   (A)   The River of Grass Cultural Arts Center Advisory Board shall consist
of nine members who shall be voting members. The members of the Board shall
consist of one designee from each of the following organizations in partnership
with the city. The Board member representing the Pembroke Pines Academic
Village shall be an appointment of the Pembroke Pines City Commission.
      (1)   Broward County Cultural Affairs Council.
      (2)   Florida International University.
      (3)   Broward Community College.
      (4)   Broward County Southwest Regional Library.
      (5)   Pembroke Pines Charter High School.
      (6)   Pembroke Pines Academic Village.
      (7)   Pembroke Pines Arts and Cultural Advisory Board.
      (8)   Pembroke Pines Parks and Recreation Department.
      (9)   South Florida Water Management District.
   (B)   Each member of the Board shall serve for a term of one year and shall
continue to serve until the expiration of his or her term, resignation, removal
for cause by the appointing organization or the City Commission, or until a
successor is designated by the appropriate organization.
   (C)   The City Manager, or his or her designee, and the Director of the
city’s Parks and Recreation Department, or his or her designee, shall serve as
ex officio, non-voting members and shall remain as permanent members of the
Board.
   (D)   No individual member of the Board may recommend their own personal,
artistic creations or cultural exhibits to the Board for display or
performance. (Ord. 1439, passed 4-2-03; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.142 MEETINGS, DATES, PROCEDURES, RECORDS AND QUORUM.
   (A)   An organizational meeting of the River of Grass Cultural Arts Center
Advisory Board shall be held as the first meeting of each year, or as soon
thereafter as practicable, for the purpose of electing officers for the ensuing
year. A Chair and Vice Chair shall be elected for terms of one year by the
Board from among its voting membership. Commencing in February 2008, at least
one regular meeting of the Board shall be held every other month and special
meetings may be called by the Chair or by any five voting members of the Board.
   (B)   The Board shall be governed by Robert’s Rules of Order, but may
otherwise propose reasonable rules of procedure to govern the conduct of its
business subject to the approval of the City Commission. All meetings, records
and files of the Board shall be open and available to the public consistent
with the Florida Public Records Law (Chapter 119, Florida Statutes) and the
Sunshine Law (Chapter 286, Florida Statutes).
   (C)   Five voting members in attendance shall constitute a quorum of the
Board. (Ord. 1439, passed 4-2-03; Am. Ord. 1600, passed 1-16-08; Am. Ord. 1697,
passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.143 REMOVAL OF MEMBERS.
   In addition to the automatic removal for the failure of a member to meet the
attendance requirements set forth in this chapter, the City Commission or
appointing organization may further remove a member of the Board for good
cause. Good cause shall be defined herein as:
   (A)   Failure to perform and perceive the functions and duties of a member
of the Board;
   (B)   Any other factor or matter within the legislative discretion of the
City Commission or appointing organization which may be considered in
determining the individual membership of a River of Grass Cultural Arts Center
Board member. (Ord. 1439, passed 4-2-03; Am. Ord. 1494, passed 9-13-04; Am.
Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.144 ASSISTANCE TO THE BOARD.
   The City Clerk, or his or her designee, shall act as secretary to the Board
and be responsible for providing the items necessary for conducting meetings,
as requested by the Chair of the Board, and for recording and preparation of
meeting minutes. The City Attorney, or his or her designee, shall act as the
attorney for the Board. (Ord. 1439, passed 4-2-03; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-
11)
§ 32.145 FUNDING.
   The City Commission shall appropriate funds at its discretion to the Board
for expenses necessary in the conduct of its work. The Board, upon the approval
of the City Commission, may accept grants or other monetary and physical
assistance to aid in its work. (Ord. 1439, passed 4-2-03; Am. Ord. 1697, passed
9-7-11)
CITIZEN BUDGET ADVISORY BOARD
§ 32.146 ESTABLISHMENT AND INTENT.
   There is hereby established the Pembroke Pines Citizen Budget Advisory Board
(the "Board"), which shall serve in an advisory capacity to the City
Commission. (Ord. 2025, passed 9-4-24)
§ 32.147 COMPOSITION AND EX-OFFICIO MEMBERS; APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS; QUORUM.
   (A)   The Citizen Budget Advisory Board shall consist of 11 members.
Additionally, the following ex-officio members shall serve as nonvoting members
and participants on the Board: the City Manager, the Finance Director, and the
Budget Director, or their respective designees; and a member of the Pembroke
Pines Police Department and a member of the Pembroke Pines Fire Department, as
designated by their respective bargaining units.
   (B)   Each member of the City Commission shall appoint two members to the
Citizen Budget Advisory Board, with the Mayor appointing three members.
      (1)   The Mayor shall appoint at least one member to the Citizen Budget
Advisory Board who has demonstrated through practice, profession, or education
to possess a specialized knowledge and understanding of budgetary or financial
matters and affairs reasonably related to the city's budget. Examples of the
requisite practice, profession, and education include educational degrees
earned or direct practical experience in one of the following or related
subject matters and careers: finance, economics, accounting, business
administration and budget analyst.
   (C)   Six members in attendance shall constitute a quorum of the Citizen
Budget Advisory Board. (Ord. 2025, passed 9-4-24)
§ 32.148 DUTIES, RESPONSIBILITIES, AND EXCLUSIONS.
   (A)   The purpose and duties of the Citizen Budget Advisory Board shall be
as follows:
      (1)   To provide the City Commission with recommendations and input
regarding the wants, needs, and expectations of the citizens and residents of
Pembroke Pines for the city's annual budget.
      (2)   To analyze and review city budget-related information including,
but not limited to, the city budget, an advanced copy of which shall be
concurrently provided to the Board and City Commission; the city's annual
comprehensive financial report; and other financial and budget-related reports
provided to the Board by the City Manager in order for the Board to offer input
to the City Commission regarding the city's millage rate and other rates to be
included in the annual Broward County Property Appraiser's Notice of Proposed
Property Taxes.
      (3)   To submit recommendations, including recommendations made by the
Board's annual report to the City Commission, to be evaluated by the Commission
ahead of its consideration of the budget for the next fiscal year.
      (4)   To advise the City Commission on matters related to the levels of
different services provided by the city and its budget priorities.
   (B)   The Board shall not make recommendations to the City Commission on the
following matters:
      (1)   Matters pertaining to the city's Pension Trust Funds and Other Post
Employment Benefit Trust Fund (OPEB), which are administered by their own
boards; and
      (2)   Matters pertaining to collective bargaining, which is governed by
state law. (Ord. 2025, passed 9-4-24)
§ 32.149 MEETINGS.
   The Citizen Budget Advisory Board shall meet at least once per month or on
an as-needed basis. (Ord. 2025, passed 9-4-24)
EDUCATION ADVISORY BOARD
§ 32.150 ESTABLISHMENT AND INTENT.
   It is the intent of the City Commission in the establishment of an Education
Advisory Board that this Board shall act in an advisory capacity to the City
Commission in matters relating to issues relating to educational matters from
the pre-school through and including post-secondary education level which will
impact the quality of education for all city residents and citizens or which
will impact education facilities located within the city. The mission of the
Education Advisory Board of the City of Pembroke Pines is to enhance education
by researching areas of concern, recommending effective programs, and creating
partnerships for those schools that are within the appropriate boundaries
enabling them to serve Pembroke Pines students. (Ord. 1500, passed 11-15-04;
Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.151 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The duties of the Education Advisory Board shall include but not be limited
to the following:
   (A)   Communicate with the administration of each school within the city as
well as those schools attended by city citizens and residents.
   (B)   Serve as a liaison between the citizens, residents, neighborhood
associations, local businesses and the city on educational issues.
   (C)   Recommend activities of the city with those activities of the local
schools, colleges and universities in order to promote educational
opportunities for citizens and residents of the city.
   (D)   Develop recommendations regarding programs which may be created to
enhance educational opportunities within the city.
   (E)   Develop proposed actions, including proposed legislation at the state
and federal level, which may be taken in support of educational programs within
the city.
   (F)   Identify and advise the city on ways to attract state and federal
programs and grants in direct support of schools within the city.
   (G)   Contact businesses within the geographical boundaries of the city and
businesses outside the geographical boundaries of the city, but who do business
with the city to provide professional skills, materials, financial or
educational support for the schools.
   (H)   Advise the city in the promotion of the public image of schools within
the city and those attended by city citizens and residents through the
development of brochures and other materials to be used in marketing city
schools.
   (I)   Collaborate and/or coordinate with the city’s police department to
improve safety for public school students before, during and after school.
   (J)   Collaborate and/or coordinate with the city’s parks and recreation
department regarding parks, playgrounds and recreational facilities and
utilization of such facilities by the schools within the city.
   (K)   Collaborate and/or coordinate, work in conjunction and communicate
regularly with the Pembroke Pines Charter Elementary and Middle School Advisory
Board and the Pembroke Pines Charter High School Advisory Board.
   (L)   Solicit participation of and regular attendance at Board meetings by
representatives of the traditional public schools located within Pembroke Pines
and those public schools serving students who reside in Pembroke Pines. (Ord.
1500, passed 11-15-04; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.152 BOARD ACTION ADVISORY ONLY.
   The actions, decisions and recommendations of the Education Advisory Board
shall not be final or binding on the City Commission but shall be advisory
only. The Board or its members shall coordinate all recommendations for
improvement in education matters in the city with the City Commission through
the City Manager, or his or her designee, and shall not interact directly with
city administration and staff, except for the purpose of inquiries,
investigations, and observations consistent with the provisions of §
3.07 of the City Charter. (Ord. 1500, passed 11-15-04; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-
7-11)
§ 32.153 ASSISTANCE TO THE BOARD.
   The City Clerk, or his or her designee, shall act as secretary to the Board
and be responsible for providing the items necessary for conducting meetings,
as requested by the Chair of the Board, and for recording and preparation of
meeting minutes. The City Attorney, or his or her designee shall act as the
attorney for the Board. (Ord. 1500, passed 11-15-04; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-
11)
AFFORDABLE HOUSING ADVISORY COMMITTEE
§ 32.160 ESTABLISHMENT.
   Pursuant to the requirements of the State of Florida Housing Initiative
Partnership Act, as may be amended from time to time, the City of Pembroke
Pines hereby established the Affordable Housing Advisory Committee. (Ord. 1606,
passed 4-16-08; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.161 COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS; TERMS OF OFFICE.
   (A)   The City Commission shall appoint, by motion, members to the
Affordable Housing Advisory Committee (the “Committee”) as provided in this
section. The Committee shall be comprised of the following individuals:
      (1)   One citizen who is actively engaged in the residential home
building industry in connection with affordable housing.
      (2)   One citizen who is actively engaged in the banking or mortgage
banking industry in connection with affordable housing.
      (3)   One citizen who is a representative of those areas of labor
actively engaged in home building in connection with affordable housing.
      (4)   One citizen who is actively engaged as an advocate for low-income
persons in connection with affordable housing.
      (5)   One citizen who is actively engaged as a for-profit provider of
affordable housing.
      (6)   One citizen who is actively engaged as a not-for-profit provider of
affordable housing.
      (7)   One citizen who is actively engaged as a real estate professional
in connection with affordable housing.
      (8)   One citizen who actively serves on the local planning agency
pursuant to F.S. § 163.3174.
      (9)   One citizen who resides within the municipal boundaries of the City
of Pembroke Pines.
      (10)   One citizen who represents employers within the City of Pembroke
Pines.
      (11)   One citizen who represents essential services personnel, as
defined in the city’s local housing assistance plan.
      (12)   One locally elected official from the city as selected by the City
Commission.
   (B)   Members of the Committee shall serve continuously at the pleasure of
the City Commission. The local elected official shall only serve while holding
the elected office.
   (C)   Appointments to fill any vacancy on the Committee shall be for the
remainder of the unexpired term of office.
   (D)   In addition to automatic removal for the failure of a member to meet
the attendance requirements set forth in this chapter, the members of the
Committee shall serve at the pleasure of the City Commission and may be removed
at any time by a majority vote of the City Commission.
   (E)   The locally elected official serving on an advisory committee, or a
locally elected designee, must attend biannual regional workshops convened and
administered under the Affordable Housing Catalyst Program. (Ord. 1606, passed
4-16-08; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11; Am. Ord. 1949, passed 9-16-20; Am. Ord.
2002, passed 12-14-22)
§ 32.162 OFFICERS; QUORUM.
   (A)   The Committee shall elect a chairperson, a vice-chairperson and such
other officers as the Committee shall deem necessary. Officers of the Committee
shall be elected by a majority vote of the membership of the Committee at its
first meeting after the members’ initial appointments, and annually thereafter.
A member of the Committee may be elected to serve as an officer without
restriction as to the number of terms served.
   (B)   The presence of six or more members shall constitute a quorum of the
Committee. (Ord. 1606, passed 4-16-08; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.163 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   (A)   As required by F.S. § 420.9076, as may be amended from time to time,
the Committee shall review the established policies and procedures, ordinances,
land development regulations, and adopted local government comprehensive plan
of the City of Pembroke Pines, and shall recommend specific actions or
initiatives to encourage or facilitate affordable housing while protecting the
ability of the property to appreciate in value.
   (B)   The Committee may perform other duties at the request of the local
government, including:
      (1)   The provision of mentoring services to affordable housing partners,
including developers, banking institutions, employers, and others to identify
available incentives, assist with applications for funding request, and develop
partnerships between various parties.
      (2)   The creation of best practices for the development of affordable
housing in the community. (Ord. 1606, passed 4-16-08; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-
7-11)
§ 32.164 ANNUAL REPORT OF THE AFFORDABLE HOUSING ADVISORY COMMITTEE.
   The Committee shall annually submit a report to the City Commission that
includes recommendations on, and evaluates the implementation of affordable
housing incentives as provided in F.S. § 420.9076(4), as may be amended from
time to time.
(Ord. 1606, passed 4-16-08; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11; Am. Ord. 1949, passed
9-16-20)
§ 32.165 CONSIDERATION AND APPROVAL OF REPORT; NOTICE; PUBLIC HEARING.
   The approval by the Committee of the City of Pembroke Pines local housing
incentive strategies recommendations, and its review of the City of Pembroke
Pines implementation of previously recommended strategies, must be made by an
affirmative vote of a majority of the membership of the Committee taken at a
public hearing. Notice of the time, date, and place of the public hearing of
the Committee to final local housing incentives strategies recommendations must
be published in a newspaper of general paid circulation in the county. The
notice must contain a short and concise summary of the local housing incentive
strategies recommendation to be considered by the Committee. The notice must
state the public place where a copy of the tentative Committee recommendations
can be obtained by interested persons. (Ord. 1606, passed 4-16-08; Am. Ord.
1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.166 CITY COMMISSION CONSIDERATION OF AFFORDABLE HOUSING ADVISORY COMMITTEE
REPORT.
   Within 90 days after the date of receipt of the local housing incentive
strategies recommendations from the Committee, the City Commission shall
consider the adoption an amendment to its local housing assistance plan to
incorporate the local housing incentive strategies it will implement within its
jurisdiction. The consideration of the amendment shall comply with the
requirements of F.S. § 420.9076(6), as may be amended from time to time. (Ord.
1606, passed 4-16-08; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.167 ASSISTANCE TO THE BOARD.
   The City Clerk or his or her designee shall act as secretary to the
Committee and be responsible for providing the items necessary for conducting
meetings, as requested by the chair of the Committee, and for recording and
preparation of meeting minutes. The City Attorney or his or her designee shall
act as the attorney for the Committee. In addition, the Committee shall be
cooperatively staffed by the appropriate city department, as determined by the
City Manager, in order to insure an integrated approach to the work of the
Committee. (Ord. 1606, passed 4-16-06; Am. Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.168 FUNDING.
   The City Commission shall appropriate funds, at its discretion, to the
Committee for expenses necessary in the conduct of its work. The Committee,
upon the approval of the City Commission, may accept grants or other monetary
and physical assistance to aid in its work. (Ord. 1606, passed 4-16-06; Am.
Ord. 1697, passed 9-7-11)
§ 32.170 HOMEOWNERS’ ASSOCIATION AND CONDOMINIUM ASSOCIATION BOARD MEMBER
EMERGENCY CONTACT INFORMATION.
   Homeowners’ associations and condominium associations, as defined by
Chapters 718 and 720, Florida Statutes, as amended from time to time,
respectively, located within the City of Pembroke Pines shall designate one of
their officers to be an emergency contact person. Each homeowners’ association
and condominium association shall provide the City Clerk the name, address and
phone number of the association’s property manager, emergency contact person,
and at least one other board member. The associations, at their discretion, may
provide the city with the contact information of additional board members to be
used in the event of an emergency or natural disaster. Current associations
shall provide the contact information of the necessary individuals no later
than June 30, 2006. Thereafter, the associations shall provide the contact
information of the necessary individuals no later than April 1 each year or
within 30 days of an election of new board members. The homeowners’ association
and condominium association are responsible for providing updated information
within 30 days in the event there is a change in their board membership. The
contact information for homeowners’ association and condominium association
board members shall only be used in accordance with Chapter 119, Florida
Statutes, as amended from time to time. (Ord. 1544, passed 5-17-06; Am. Ord.
1697, passed 9-7-11)
PUBLIC ART COMMITTEE
§ 32.180 ESTABLISHMENT AND MISSION.
   (A)   There is hereby established a committee to be known as the "Public Art
Committee."
   (B)   The mission of the Public Art Committee is to expand cultural
opportunities for residents and visitors and to enhance the appearance of the
city through the selection and integration of artwork in a public environment.
   (C)   Members of the Public Art Committee shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 1960, passed 3-3-21)
§ 32.181 COMPOSITION.
   (A)   Notwithstanding §§
32.002 through
32.004, the Public Art Committee consists of seven regular members, who live or
conduct business in the city, with a strong commitment to the objectives of the
public art program, who unless otherwise stated shall be appointed by the City
Manager, or his/her designee. Membership of the Public Art Committee may
include:
      (1)   Three individuals chosen from the following disciplines: landscape
architecture, urban planning, engineering, or a related design discipline;
      (2)   One professional artist, whose primary source of income is through
the sale of original art or art instruction;
      (3)   One resident, knowledgeable in the field of public art, education,
or community affairs;
      (4)   One private citizen from the development community; and
      (5)   One member of the Arts and Culture Board selected by a majority of
the Arts and Culture Board.
   (D)   Membership terms. To provide for staggered terms, the individuals
appointed pursuant to divisions (A)(1) and (A)(2) shall serve for an initial
term of three years from the date of appointment; and the individuals appointed
pursuant to divisions (A)(3), (A)(4) and (A)(5) shall serve for an initial term
of one year from the date of appointment. Thereafter, all appointees shall be
appointed to serve for a term of three years from the date of appointment.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, all board members shall continue to serve until
their successors are appointed pursuant to this section.
   (E)   Any member of the Public Art Committee that misses three consecutive
Committee meetings may be replaced by the City Manager, at the City Manager's
sole discretion. (Ord. 1960, passed 3-3-21)
§ 32.182 MEETINGS.
   (A)   The Public Art Committee shall meet at least once per quarter or on an
as needed basis.
   (B)   Other meetings will be held as necessary to carry out the duties and
responsibilities of the Committee.
   (C)   Four members of the Public Art Committee shall constitute a quorum.
(Ord. 1960, passed 3-3-21)
§ 32.183 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Public Art Committee shall have the following powers and duties:
   (A)   Recommendations to the City Manager through the Department Director or
Liaison, on revisions to the public art master plan, as set forth in §
97.42.
   (B)   Recommendations to the City Manager through the Department Director or
Liaison, on art and artist selection. (Ord. 1960, passed 3-3-21)
§ 32.184 CONFLICTS OF INTEREST PROHIBITED.
   No member of the Public Art Committee shall have his/her work of art
considered or approved by the Public Art Committee during their term of service
on the Committee or for one year thereafter; nor shall any member of the Public
Art Committee derive a financial gain as a result of their service on the
Committee during their term of service or for one year thereafter. (Ord. 1960,
passed 3-3-21)
DIVERSITY AND HERITAGE ADVISORY BOARD
§ 32.190 ESTABLISHMENT AND MISSION.
   (A)   There is hereby established a Board to be known as the “Diversity and
Heritage Advisory Board.”
   (B)   The mission of the Diversity and Heritage Advisory Board is to promote
awareness and to celebrate the rich heritage and the vast diversity of the
city.
(Ord. 1928, passed 6-19-19)
§ 32.191 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Diversity and Heritage Advisory Board shall have the following power and
duties:
   (A)   Recommendations to the Commission on diversity and equity strategies
that strengthen connections among diverse community groups and with city
government.
   (B)   Recommendations to the Commission on exploring new methods and
techniques to acknowledge tangible and intangible cultural heritage and expand
recognition programs related to heritage preservation activities.
   (C)   Recommendations to the Commission on ways to work with public and
private stakeholders in the city to increase understanding of the diverse
groups that make up the city.
(Ord. 1928, passed 6-19-19)
§ 32.192 COMPOSITION AND QUORUM.
   (A)   The Diversity and Heritage Advisory Board consists of 15 regular
members and ten alternates, who live or conduct business in the city, with a
strong commitment to the mission of the Diversity and Heritage Advisory Board.
The Mayor and each City Commissioner shall appoint three regular members. The
Mayor shall appoint two alternates and each City Commissioner shall appoint two
alternates. Alternates may only be appointed from the district in which the
appointing Commissioner resides; with the exception of the Mayor's
appointments, who may reside in any district. Alternates may only be seated at
a meeting for voting and quorum purposes in the absence of a regular member.
There shall be a rotation of alternate members by district to vote in the
absence of a regular member from the same or different district.
   (B)   In the event that a Diversity and Heritage Advisory Board meeting does
not have a quorum, the first alternate members shall be from the same district
of the absent member for voting and quorum purposes.
   (C)   However, in a meeting in which there are no alternates from the
district of the absent member present, then alternate members from another
district or a Mayor’s appointee shall be seated for voting and quorum purposes
through a rotation process.
   (D)   Once the rotation goes through the appointees from the four districts
and the Mayor’s appointees, then the rotation shall start over from District 1.
   (E)   In the rotation process, the Clerk or the Clerk’s designee shall
designate the alternate being seated for quorum and voting purposes based on
where the last meeting ended. If at the last two meetings a district or Mayor’s
appointee was seated for voting or quorum purposes, then at the next two
meetings, the next alternate in the rotation shall be from the next consecutive
district or a Mayor’s appointee. For example, if the District 1 alternates are
not present when it is their turn in the rotation, then the alternates from
District 2 would be next in the rotation. However, if the alternates from
District 2 are not available, then the alternates from District 3 would be next
in the rotation. This pattern would continue for District 4 and the Mayor’s
appointed alternates.
   (F)   In the event that a District’s alternates are not present at a meeting
in which it is their turn in the rotation, then the next time those alternates
will be called in the rotation will be in the normal course pursuant to this
section.
   (G)   Notwithstanding the foregoing, every alternate present at each
meeting, regardless of whether they are seated for voting and quorum purposes,
shall have the opportunity to participate in the meeting.
   (H)   Eight voting members in attendance shall constitute a quorum of the
Board. (Ord. 1928, passed 6-19-19; Am. Ord. 1933, passed 9-18-19; Am. Ord.
2004, passed 4-4-23)
§ 32.193 MEETINGS.
   The Diversity and Heritage Advisory Board shall meet at least once per
quarter or on an as needed basis. Other meetings may be held as necessary to
carry out the duties and responsibilities of the Board.
(Ord. 1928, passed 6-19-19)
§ 32.194 BOARD ACTION ADVISORY ONLY.
   The actions, decisions and recommendations of the Diversity and Heritage
Advisory Board shall not be final or binding on the City Commission, but shall
be advisory only.
(Ord. 1928, passed 6-19-19)
§ 32.195 ASSISTANCE TO THE BOARD.
   The City Clerk or his/her designee shall act as Secretary to the Board and
be responsible for providing the items necessary for conducting meetings, as
requested by the Chair of the Board, and for recording and preparation of
meeting minutes.
(Ord. 1928, passed 6-19-19)
YOUTH ADVISORY BOARD
§ 32.197 CREATION.
   (A)   Creation. There is hereby created and established the City of Pembroke
Pines Youth Advisory Board (“Board”). Unless otherwise expressly provided for
herein, the requirements of City Code of Ordinances §§
32.001 to
32.011, shall apply to the Board.
   (B)   Appointments. It is the intention and purpose of this subchapter that
the school principals of (1) Franklin Academy; (2) West Broward High School;
(3) Somerset Academy; (4) Flanagan High School; and (5) Pines Charter High
School shall each recommend to the City Manager no more than three students to
fill vacant positions on the Board. Each school shall have no more than three
appointments to the Board at any one time. Up to two students that are
residents, as defined in subsection (C), but do not attend one of the five
school listed above, may also submit an application to the City Manager for
consideration of appointment to the Board to fill vacant positions. The total
membership of this Board shall be comprised of no more than 17 members. A
majority of the members appointed to the Board shall constitute a quorum.
   (C)   Eligibility. In making appointments to this Board, consideration shall
be given to seeking student members who reside in the city. All Board members
must currently reside in the city, be enrolled in grades ten through 12, and be
no less than 14 years old. All Board members must maintain at least a 2.5 GPA.
All members must be recommended by the principal of their respective school or
submit an application to the City Manager and each student must be approved by
the City Manager to serve on the Board.
   (D)   Term. The selection of Board members shall take place at the start of
each school year during the month of August. Notwithstanding the requirements
of City Code of Ordinances §
32.005, the term of appointment for Board members shall continue for a period
of up to three years. The term of appointment for Board members shall conclude
during the month of May. Members of the Board shall be removed by the City
Manager for missing three consecutive Board meetings, and may be removed by the
City Manager, in his/her sole discretion.
   (E)   Community service hours. Members of the Board may be eligible to
receive official credit for school and community service hours for their
participation with the Board if permitted by the overseeing authority.
   (F)   Frequency of meetings. The Board shall meet one time each month during
the school year, or more frequently if desired by the Board.
   (G)   Scholarship. Any Board member serving on the Board for two or more
years shall, at graduation, be eligible for a city scholarship of up to $1,000.
(Ord. 2000, passed 11-16-22; Am. Ord. 2013, passed 11-15-23)
§ 32.198 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   The powers and duties of the Youth Advisory Board shall be advisory in
nature to the City Commission, but solely by and through the professional staff
of the Recreation & Cultural Arts Department, and the City's Administration.
The duties of the Board shall include but not be limited to the following:
      (1)   Identifying, researching, and analyzing issues impacting youth in
the community;
      (2)   Advising the City Commission on matters impacting youth residing in
and attending schools within the city;
      (3)   Recommending social, educational, cultural and recreational
activities for youth within the city, and to assist with implementing those
activities;
      (4)   Assisting with any other matters assigned to the Board by the City
Manager; and
      (5)   Organizing or performing services or functions approved and
directed by the City Manager.
   (B)   Service events. Board members shall participate in various events held
by the city which give back to the community.
(Ord. 2000, passed 11-16-22)
CODE OF ETHICS
§ 32.200 CODE OF ETHICS FOR QUASI-JUDICIAL ADVISORY BOARD MEMBERS.
   (A)   Statement of policy. It is the policy of the City of Pembroke Pines
that the members of the city's quasi-judicial advisory boards work for the
benefit of the citizens and residents of the city. It is the responsibility of
each quasi-judicial advisory board member to act in a manner that promotes
public trust and confidence in government with complete transparency and
honesty in their services, and to avoid even the appearance or perception of
impropriety.
   (B)   Financial disclosure. Each quasi-judicial advisory board member,
contemporaneous with the filing of the Form 1 Statement of Financial Interests
with the Supervisor of Elections, shall file such form with the City Clerk.
Form 1 filed pursuant to this section shall be made available on the city's
website for public inspection.
   (C)   Lobbyists. Quasi-judicial advisory board members should avoid even the
appearance of impropriety in their interaction and dealings with lobbyists
registered under the city's lobbyist registration system and with the
principals or employers of such lobbyists.
      (1)   To promote full and complete transparency, lobbyists and their
principals or employers who intend to meet or otherwise communicate with a
member of a quasi-judicial advisory board for the purpose of engaging in
lobbying activities, either at City Hall or elsewhere on city property, must
legibly complete a contact log listing each board member with whom the
lobbyist, principal or employer meets or intends on meeting or communicating.
         (a)   The information stated on the contact log shall include the
lobbyist's name; the name of the entity by which the lobbyist is employed; the
name of the person or entity for whom or which he or she is lobbying; the name
of each board member with whom he or she is meeting or communicating; the date
and time of each such meeting; and the specific purpose and subject matter of
each such meeting.
         (b)   The contact log shall be completed contemporaneously with the
meetings and shall be made available for inspection on the city's website.
      (2)   To further propose full and complete transparency, quasi-judicial
board members must disclose any and all lobbying activities that knowingly
occurs between themselves and individual lobbyists or their principals or
employers outside of City Hall or off city-owned property. This shall include
communicating by any form of telephonic or electronic media.
         (a)   The disclosure shall be made on a form provided by the City
Clerk's Office. This disclosure shall include the lobbyist's name; the name of
the entity by which the lobbyist is employed; the name of the person or entity
for whom or which he or she is lobbying; the date, time. and location of the
meeting; and the specific purpose and subject matter of the meeting.
         (b)   The disclosure shall be made within ten business days of the
lobbying activity; but must, in any event, be made prior to any vote on the
matter that was the subject of the lobbying activity.
         (c)   The disclosure shall be made available for inspection on the
city's website.
   (D)   Any member of a quasi-judicial advisory board who fails to comply with
this section shall be deemed non-qualified to serve and removed from the board.
(Ord. 1766, passed 12-18-13)
