VESTED RIGHTS
§ 156.40 VESTED RIGHTS AVAILABLE.
   Any property owner or developer may seek a vested rights determination
regarding a specific parcel for which additional intensity or density is
sought.
(Ord. 936, passed 10-17-90)
§ 156.41 REQUESTS TO BE FILED WITH CITY MANAGER; INFORMATION REQUIRED.
   (A)   Requests for vested rights determination shall be filed with the City
Manager. The developer shall be required to state the parcel for which the
vested rights determination is sought, the basis for the vested rights claim,
and shall provide a copy of the agreement or other document which the developer
asserts gives rise to a vested rights determination.
   (B)   After the developer has filed for a vested rights determination it
shall be forwarded to the City Attorney for review.
(Ord. 936, passed 10-17-90)
§ 156.42 HEARING OFFICER TO CONDUCT ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING.
   (A)   A hearing officer shall be appointed to conduct an administrative
hearing regarding the vested rights determination. The procedures for
conducting hearings shall be approved by a resolution of the City Commission
and incorporated in the Administrative Code. The hearing shall be set for no
later than 60 days from the date of filing unless an extension of time is
requested or agreed to by the applicant.
   (B)   The City Attorney shall represent the city in the administrative
hearing. The hearing officer shall determine whether vested rights have been
created pursuant to statute or established case law and shall determine whether
any time limitation is applicable to such vested rights.
(Ord. 936, passed 10-17-90)
§ 156.43 ELIMINATION OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING.
   If the City Attorney, any time before the hearing, reviews the application
and finds that the application has provided clear evidence that vested rights
claimed by the developer exist, the City Attorney and the applicant may
stipulate to the existence of vested rights and the time during which such
rights may be exercised. Such stipulation shall eliminate the need for
determination by the hearing officer.
(Ord. 936, passed 10-17-90)
§ 156.44 HEARING OFFICER AND CITY COMMISSION TO ISSUE PROPOSED ORDER.
   (A)   The hearing officer shall, within 45 days of the hearing, issue a
proposed order which shall include findings of fact and conclusions of law with
respect to the claim of vested rights.
   (B)   The City Commission shall within 30 days of receipt of the proposed
order issue its determination which shall be in the form of resolution.
(Ord. 936, passed 10-17-90)
CHAPTER 157: LOCAL HOUSING ASSISTANCE PROGRAM
Section
   
157.01   Definitions
   
157.02   Findings; legislative intent
   
157.03   Establishment of Local Housing Assistance Program
   
157.04   Effect on Joint Local Housing Assistance Program
   
157.05   Establishment of Affordable Housing Assistance Trust Fund
   
157.06   Expansion of existing Citizens Advisory Committee
   
157.07   Implementation of the Affordable Housing Incentive Plan approved by
the City Commission
§ 157.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the definitions contained in the State
Housing Initiatives Partnership Act (“Act”), and Chapter 9I-37, Florida
Administrative Code, as they may be amended from time to time, are adopted
herein by reference.
(Ord. 1119, passed 4-19-95; Am. Ord. 1232, passed 10-8-97)
§ 157.02 FINDINGS; LEGISLATIVE INTENT.
   (A)   Findings.
      (1)   The State Housing Initiatives Partner- ship Act (“Act”) provides
for the establishment of local housing assistance programs;
      (2)   The city wishes to provide for the housing needs of its citizens,
and to promote the efficient location, design, and provision of affordable
housing;
      (3)   The city desires to establish a local housing assistance program;
and
      (4)   Ordinance 1119, passed 4-19-95, establishing the Local Housing
Assistance Program of the city remains in effect until the monies allocated
under the 1997-1998 Fiscal Year Program are expended in accordance with such
ordinance.
   (B)   Legislative intent. The purpose of this chapter is to implement the
Act, including, without limitation, the following:
      (1)   To increase the availability of affordable housing by combining
local resources and cost saving measures, as applicable, and by using private
and public resources to reduce the cost of housing;
      (2)   To promote more compact urban development, and to assist in
achieving the growth management goals contained in the adopted local
comprehensive plan by allowing more efficient use of land so as to provide
housing units that are more affordable;
      (3)   To establish a strong sense of community through increased social
and economic integration;
      (4)   To build the organizational and technical capacity of community-
based organizations so as to optimize the role of community-based organizations
in the production of affordable housing;
      (5)   To promote innovative design of eligible housing, and its
supporting infrastructure, to provide for cost savings in the provisions of
such housing;
      (6)   To promote expedited permit processing systems for affordable
housing; and
      (7)   To promote review procedure for plan provisions that impact
affordable housing.
(Ord. 1119, passed 4-19-95; Am. Ord. 1232, passed 10-8-97)
§ 157.03 ESTABLISHMENT OF LOCAL HOUSING ASSISTANCE PROGRAM.
   (A)   There is created and established a Local Housing Assistance Program
(“Program”) by the city, to be implemented and administrated by the city.
   (B)   The city shall implement the Program, within the city, consistently
with the requirements of the Act. The strategies of the Program will be
outlined in the city’s State Housing Initiatives Partnership Housing Assistance
Plan.
(Ord. 1119, passed 4-19-95; Am. Ord. 1232, passed 10-8-97)
§ 157.04 EFFECT ON JOINT LOCAL HOUSING ASSISTANCE PROGRAM.
   The Local Housing Assistance Program for the city, as established by
Ordinance 1119, passed 4-19-95, shall remain in effect until the monies
allocated under the 1997-1998 Fiscal Program Year are expended in accordance
with the terms of such ordinance.
(Ord. 1119, passed 4-19-95; Am. Ord. 1232, passed 10-8-97)
§ 157.05 ESTABLISHMENT OF AFFORDABLE HOUSING ASSISTANCE TRUST FUND.
   (A)   Pursuant to the requirements of the Act, the city agrees to provide
for the continuance of the existing affordable housing trust fund (“Fund”)
within the official and fiscal accounting records of the city. All monies
deposited in the fund shall be subject to the requirements of the Act and the
city ordinance establishing the fund.
   (B)   The city shall cause the Fund to be audited and shall report the
results of such audit as required by the Act.
(Ord. 1119, passed 4-19-95; Am. Ord. 1232, passed 10-8-97)
§ 157.06 EXPANSION OF EXISTING CITIZENS ADVISORY COMMITTEE.
   The Citizens Advisory Committee currently in existence in the city shall be
expanded to act in the role of the Affordable Housing Advisory Committee, as
required by the Act. Composition of the existing Committee shall be nine
members serving one year terms. Members of the Committee shall be appointed by
Commission pursuant to the requirements of this chapter.
(Ord. 1119, passed 4-19-95; Am. Ord. 1232, passed 10-8-97; Am. Ord. 1258,
passed 4-15-98)
§ 157.07 IMPLEMENTATION OF THE AFFORDABLE HOUSING INCENTIVE PLAN APPROVED BY
THE CITY COMMISSION.
   The Affordable Housing Assistance Incentive Plan (“Incentive Plan”) for the
city, as approved by the City Commission, shall remain in effect and shall act
as Incentive Strategies for the city’s Program, in accordance with the
requirements of the Act. Incentive Strategies shall be incorporated into the
Local Housing Assistance Program pursuant to the requirements of the Act.
(Ord. 1119, passed 4-19-95; Am. Ord. 1232, passed 10-8-97; Am. Ord. 1258,
passed 4-15-98)
CHAPTER 158: AFFORDABLE HOUSING PROGRAM
Section
   
158.01   Purpose
   
158.02   Definitions
   
158.03   Affordable Housing Trust Fund
   
158.04   Commission of independent affordable housing study
   
158.05   City center project affordable housing initiative
   
158.06   Monitoring and review
Cross-reference:
   Affordable Housing Advisory Committee, see §§ 32.400 through 32.409
§ 158.01 PURPOSE.
   (A)   The purpose of this chapter is to implement a tiered ordinance to
establish guidelines and criteria for a housing assistance program(s) to
provide a variety of housing options ranging from homeownership to rental for
families earning 150% of the median income of the city or less.
   (B)   The first tier of this ordinance shall establish an affordable housing
trust fund to receive funds from voluntary contributions as well as state and
federal aid, and may direct the City Manager, by resolution, to commission an
outside, independent study to examine the city's affordable housing needs and
conditions. The second tier of this ordinance may thereafter incorporate the
findings of this study.
(Ord. 1575, passed 3-21-07)
§ 158.02 DEFINITIONS.
   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall
have the meanings ascribed to them as set forth below, except where the context
clearly indicates a different meaning.
   AFFORDABLE HOUSING TRUST FUND. Trust Fund established by the city for the
purpose of collecting the required fees and disbursing funds for affordable
housing programs in accordance with the criteria set forth herein.
   AFFORDABLE HOUSING UNIT. Housing built with funding from federal, state,
local or private resources and designated for affordable housing for moderate,
low and very low income households.
   CITY. The City of Pembroke Pines, Florida.
   ELIGIBLE HOUSEHOLD. A household that qualifies for participation in an
affordable housing program as designated in this chapter.
   HOUSEHOLD. One person living alone or two or more persons sharing residency
whose income is considered for the affordable housing program.
   OWNER. The person or persons who hold title to the property as indicated in
the Broward County Public Records and is the mortgagor.
   SHARED APPRECIATION. Percentage of the amount of the appreciation in the
value of the affordable housing unit to be shared by the city and owner at the
time of resale of the affordable housing unit.
(Ord. 1575, passed 3-21-07)
§ 158.03 AFFORDABLE HOUSING TRUST FUND.
   The city shall establish an Affordable Housing Trust Fund for the purpose of
collecting any and all funds related to the city’s affordable housing programs
pursuant to this chapter. Such funds shall include, but not be limited to,
voluntary contributions and state and federal assistance, including Community
Development Block Grant (CDBG) funding, State Housing Initiative Partnership
(SHIP) and the Home Investment Partnership Program (HOME), and shared
appreciation dollars collected at the closing of sales of designated
properties.
   (A)   The funds collected for deposit in the Affordable Housing Trust Fund
may be utilized for the following affordable housing programs:
      (1)   Down payment assistance to eligible households;
      (2)   Acquisition and construction of affordable housing units;
      (3)   Enhancement of county, state and federal affordable housing
programs; and
      (4)   Rehabilitation of existing affordable housing units.
   (B)   The City Commission may from time to time by resolution authorize
additional programs which may be funded through the Affordable Housing Trust
Fund.
   (C)   The City Manager, or his or her designee, shall provide the required
supervision for the Affordable Housing Trust Fund and shall oversee the
account. A financial status report on the Affordable Housing Trust Account
shall be provided to the City Commission on or before October 1 of each
calendar year.
(Ord. 1575, passed 3-21-07)
§ 158.04 COMMISSION OF INDEPENDENT AFFORDABLE HOUSING STUDY.
   The City Commission recognizes the future need for additional analysis of
the city's affordable housing needs, and may authorize the City Manager, or his
or her designee, by resolution, to commission an independent study of the
city’s affordable housing needs and conditions. This affordable housing study
shall examine the following issues, among other things: affordable rental
options, initial purchases, future and subsequent sales of affordable housing
units, qualifications of eligible households, priority for available units, and
the demand for affordable housing. The findings of this study may be
incorporated into the city's Code of Ordinances as the second tier of this
chapter.
(Ord. 1575, passed 3-21-07)
§ 158.05 CITY CENTER PROJECT AFFORDABLE HOUSING INITIATIVE.
   (A)   At least 250 units in the city’s City Center project have been
previously designated as affordable or workforce housing units on the City
Center Plat, and shall retain such designation in perpetuity, but subject
nonetheless to the guidelines established herein and in a future master
declaration of covenants and restrictions to be filed and recorded by the city
or its successor. Notwithstanding other provisions of this section, the City
Center affordable housing shall mean housing for which monthly rents or monthly
mortgage payments (including taxes and insurance) do not exceed 30% of an
amount representing 120% of the median incomes adjusted for family size for all
households within the city; provided however, that the definition of affordable
housing for City Center shall also include workforce housing or any similar
concept if adopted and defined as part of the Broward County Land Use Plan.
   (B)   These units, if and when designated and constructed shall only be sold
or rented to qualified buyers or tenants as defined herein, pursuant to the
city's Code of Ordinances and Florida Statutes, as amended from time to time.
This restriction shall be included in future deeds of conveyance for each of
the affordable housing units referenced in this division or in a master
declaration of restrictive covenants.
(Ord. 1575, passed 3-21-07)
§ 158.06 MONITORING AND REVIEW.
   (A)   The City Manager, or his or her designee, shall monitor the
implementation of this chapter. On or before October 1 of each calendar, the
City Manager shall present a status report to the City Commission on the
implementation of this chapter.
   (B)   One year after the adoption of this chapter, the City Commission shall
review its implementation and effectiveness.
(Ord. 1575, passed 3-21-07)
CHAPTER 159: SPECIAL DISTRICTS
Section
   
159.01   Safe Neighborhood Improvement Districts
§ 159.01 SAFE NEIGHBORHOOD IMPROVEMENT DISTRICTS.
   (A)   The City Commission hereby finds and declares that among the many
causes of deterioration in the business and residential neighborhoods of the
state are the following: proliferation of crime, automobile traffic flow
strangled by outmoded street patterns, unsuitable topography, faulty lot
layouts, fragmentation of land uses and parking areas necessitating frequent
automobile movement, lack of separation of pedestrian areas from automobile
traffic, lack of separation of vehicle traffic lanes and railroad traffic, and
excessive noise levels from automobile traffic.
   (B)   The City Commission further finds and declares that safe neighborhoods
are the product of planning and implementation of appropriate environmental
design concepts, comprehensive crime prevention programs, land use
recommendations, and beautification techniques.
   (C)   The City Commission further finds and declares that the provisions of
this part and the powers granted to local governments, property owners'
associations, special dependent districts, and community redevelopment
neighborhood improvement districts are desirable to guide and accomplish the
coordinated, balanced, and harmonious development of safe neighborhoods; to
promote the health, safety, and general welfare of these areas and their
inhabitants, visitors, property owners, and workers; to establish, maintain,
and preserve property values and preserve and foster the development of
attractive neighborhood and business environments: to prevent overcrowding and
congestion: to improve or redirect automobile traffic and provide pedestrian
safety; to reduce crime rates and the opportunities for the commission of
crime; and to provide improvements in neighborhoods so they are defensible
against crime.
   (D)   It is the intent of the City Commission to authorize the creation of
Safe Neighborhood Improvement Districts as provided in F.S. §§ 163.501 through
163.526, also known as the Safe Neighborhood Improvement Act (the "Act"), to
assist the City in implementing plans that employ crime prevention through
community policing innovations, environmental design, environmental security,
and defensible space techniques to establish safe neighborhoods. The
Legislature, therefore, declares that the development, redevelopment,
preservation, and revitalization of neighborhoods in this state, and all the
purposes of this part, are public purposes for which public money may be
borrowed, expended, loaned, and granted.
(Ord. 1988, passed 5-4-22)
